content: The "Nuclear Terrorism Prevention Act of 2006" may be cited as the short title. Definitions are provided in Section 2. The "Nuclear Terrorism Prevention Act of 2006" defines key terms such as the Convention on the Physical Protection of Nuclear Material, design-basis threat, and formula quantities of strategic special nuclear material. The "Nuclear Terrorism Prevention Act of 2006" defines terms like Nuclear Non-Proliferation Treaty, nuclear weapon as any device using atomic energy for weapon purposes. The term "nuclear weapon" is defined as any device utilizing atomic energy for weapon purposes, excluding the means for transporting or propelling the device. SEC. 3. FINDINGS. Congress finds that the threat of terrorists acquiring and using a nuclear weapon is urgent and poses a significant risk to national and global security. While progress has been made in securing nuclear stockpiles and combating nuclear terrorism, additional efforts are necessary to further reduce this threat. The White House's 2006 National Strategy for Combating Terrorism emphasizes the grave danger of weapons of mass destruction in the hands of terrorists, and the United Nations Secretary-General has warned of the catastrophic impact of a nuclear terror attack. The White House's 2006 National Strategy for Combating Terrorism highlights the grave threat of weapons of mass destruction in terrorist hands. UN Secretary-General Kofi Annan warns of the devastating impact of a nuclear terror attack, including widespread death, economic turmoil, and increased poverty. UN Security Council Resolution 1540 (2004) emphasizes the need for all countries to adopt and enforce effective laws to combat terrorist threats to international peace and security. The need to combat terrorist threats to international peace and security by prohibiting non-state actors from acquiring and using weapons of mass destruction, particularly for terrorist purposes, is emphasized. The Director General of the International Atomic Energy Agency warns of the urgent need to prevent a terrorist attack using a nuclear weapon. The Sense of Congress on the prevention of nuclear terrorism is emphasized in Section 4. The sense of Congress emphasizes the need for a comprehensive approach to reduce the threat of nuclear terror, including efforts to eliminate terrorist groups seeking nuclear weapons, secure nuclear materials worldwide, and prevent terrorist manufacturing or transportation of nuclear explosives. The comprehensive strategy to prevent nuclear terrorism includes securing all nuclear weapons and special nuclear material globally, prioritizing the prevention of a nuclear terrorist attack on the United States, and accelerating programs to combat nuclear smuggling and secure nuclear materials. The International Atomic Energy Agency's role is crucial in this effort. The President should accelerate programs to prevent nuclear terrorism, combat nuclear smuggling, and secure strategic nuclear material. The International Atomic Energy Agency plays a vital role in coordinating international efforts to protect nuclear materials. Legislation sponsored by Senators Lugar, Domenici, and Nunn has led to groundbreaking programs to prevent nuclear weapons from falling into the hands of terrorists. The National Security Act of 1947 is amended to include a new section for a senior advisor to the president for the prevention of nuclear terrorism. Legislation sponsored by Senators Lugar, Domenici, and Nunn has been instrumental in preventing nuclear weapons from falling into the hands of terrorists. The National Security Act of 1947 is amended to include a Senior Advisor to the President for the Prevention of Nuclear Terrorism. The advisor is appointed by the President with Senate approval and is responsible for advising on nuclear terrorism matters, formulating prevention policies, and addressing gaps in existing programs to prevent nuclear terrorism. The Senior Advisor to the President for the Prevention of Nuclear Terrorism is responsible for advising on nuclear terrorism matters, formulating prevention policies, overseeing program development, budget requests, and identifying new initiatives to prevent nuclear terrorism. They also coordinate United States efforts to implement these policies. They also coordinate US efforts to implement these policies. The Senior Advisor may appoint necessary personnel to perform their duties. The Senior Advisor to the President for the Prevention of Nuclear Terrorism is added as a member of the National Security Council. The Senior Advisor to the President for the Prevention of Nuclear Terrorism is added as a member of the National Security Council. SEC. 6 requires an annual report. The President, in consultation with the Senior Advisor for the Prevention of Nuclear Terrorism, must submit an annual report to Congress on the security of strategic special nuclear material. The report includes information on the program for removal and security of nuclear weapons and materials worldwide. The Ronald W. Reagan National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2005 requires a survey of facilities worldwide containing nuclear weapons and materials, with a list of high-priority sites for removal or security of such materials. The Ronald W. Reagan National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2005 mandates a survey of global facilities with nuclear weapons and materials, prioritizing sites for securing or removing such materials, along with a plan and efforts by governments to secure them. The report mandated by the Ronald W. Reagan National Defense Authorization Act for Fiscal Year 2005 includes a detailed plan for securing nuclear weapons and materials at vulnerable facilities worldwide, along with efforts to establish security standards and policies. The report may be submitted in classified form but must include a detailed unclassified summary. SEC. 7 outlines the minimum security standard for nuclear weapons and strategic special nuclear materials. The United States policy is to ensure the security and accountability of all nuclear weapons and special nuclear materials. In line with international standards, the President will work towards a global agreement on nuclear security to effectively protect these materials. The President aims to establish a global standard for nuclear security, ensuring protection against threats from terrorists and criminals, considering equipment and human limitations, and implementing verifiable measures. International efforts will be made to collaborate with other countries and the International Atomic Energy Agency. The President, through international efforts, will work with other countries and the International Atomic Energy Agency to upgrade nuclear security measures globally and provide financial and technical assistance where needed. The President aims to rapidly upgrade security measures to meet international standards, sustain these measures post-assistance, provide financial and technical aid for security upgrades, and collaborate with other countries to enforce effective nuclear security rules globally. The President aims to ensure effective nuclear security rules, regulation, and enforcement globally, including implementing a regulatory design-basis threat model to counter threats from terrorists and criminals. Authorization of appropriations for fiscal year 2008 totaling $50,000,000 to increase international participation in converting nuclear facilities from highly enriched uranium to low enriched uranium and to remove highly enriched uranium from such facilities.
